Hailed in Boston as a masterpiece, "Tugboat" set the stage for Galaxie 500Ã¢â‚¬â„¢s first album, Today, which they recorded with Kramer (for $750) in the summer of 1988. Melody Maker called the LP "an astonishing debut by anybodyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s standards," and indeed it is. The incredible, supple beauty that Galaxie spun like straw was so sweetly melancholic that it all but smothered you. DamonÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s drums drift with the simmering presence of jazz classicism, NaomiÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s bass is rich with dreamy emotional content, DeanÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s guitar completes the aural landscapes begun by Ã¢â‚¬Ëœ69-era Sterling Morrison, and the vocals emerge from the Ouija board of eternity. A highlight of Today is the incredible primal-drone-hunch treatment the band gives to Jonathan RichmanÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s "DonÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t Let Our Youth Go to Waste." The three extra tracks from this session, included on the box set, would have made Sonic YouthÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Thurston Moore fiercer in his declaration of Today as "my favorite guitar record of 1988."
